entry.title: Stevie Ray Vaughan: 27 Years Gone
entry.content:
August 27, 1990 was a tragic day for the world of music; the day that Stevie Ray Vaughan boarded a helicopter that would never make it out of Alpine Valley in East Troy, WI. The helicopter crashed into a hill in dense fog around midnight following a concert. SRV, 3 of Eric Clapton's entourage, and the pilot, were all killed. I can only wonder and imagine what Stevie would be up to these days if he were still around.

I didn't know who Stevie was until I was around 20 years old, but he changed everything for me. Here's a little of the story about how I discovered him, as I told it on Instagram last year on what would have been his 62nd birthday.

"The first time that I heard one of Stevie's songs was while I was working at Chili's, circa 1997. "Pride and Joy" was one of the songs on one of our compilation CD's that played throughout the restaurant. I still remember right where I was, bussing a table, when it came on. I had never listened to the blues or anything directly influenced by it before. I was very much into 90's rock at the time. But that song changed everything; I was hooked. Thank you, Stevie, for opening up my world."

I'll definitely be listening to some Stevie Ray Vaughan and Double Trouble in honor of SRV. If you haven't discovered his music yet, I highly recommend that you do so immediately.Â
